abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for Zambia - Power
            Rehabilitation Project were as follows: outcomes were
            satisfactory, the sustainability was unlikely, the
            institutional development impact was moderate, the Bank
            performance was satisfactory, and the borrower performance
            was unsatisfactory. Lessons learned from the project:
            critical policy actions need to be addressed up-front, when
            including unrelated, but socially desirable components to a
            project, care must be taken to ensure that the implementing
            agency has the requisite skills and experience in
            implementing them. Power rehabilitation projects are much
            more complex than green field power projects. The elements
            of power sector reform need to include, as a minimum,
            commercialization of the power sector institutions, with
            functionally independent generation, transmission and
            distributions entities, and with clearly established
            transfer pricing arrangement among these entities. Community
            involvement in the design of IDA projects should be
            encouraged, whenever such project impacts on people and the
            environment. Governments should not use utilities to provide
            disguised subsidies to special classes of consumers. The
            Bank should help borrowers understand the full potential of
            modern business information systems. Senior managers of
            utilities need training. Cross conditions of effectiveness
            with other lenders to the same project should be spelled out
            in detail and included in the risk analysis of the PAD.
